dt: {bc}a burning stick of resinous wood or twist of tow used to give light and usually carried in the hand {bc}{sx|flambeau||}
{bc}something (such as tradition, wisdom, or knowledge) likened to a torch as giving light or guidance

dt.t: pass the {wi}torch{/wi} to the next generation

dt: {bc}any of various portable devices for emitting an unusually hot flame {dx}compare {dxt|blowtorch||}{/dx}

et: Middle English {it}torche{/it}, from Anglo-French, from Vulgar Latin {it}*torca{/it}, alteration of Latin {it}torqua{/it} something twisted, collar of twisted metal, alteration of {it}torques{/it}; akin to Latin {it}torquēre{/it} to twist {ma}{mat|torture:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: a burning stick of resinous wood or twist of tow used to give light and usually carried in the hand : flambeau
something (such as tradition, wisdom, or knowledge) likened to a torch as giving light or guidance
any of various portable devices for emitting an unusually hot flame

dt: {bc}to set fire to with or as if with a torch

shortdef: to set fire to with or as if with a torch

dt: {bc}a popular sentimental song of unrequited love

et: from the phrase {it}to carry a torch for{/it} (to be in love)
shortdef: a popular sentimental song of unrequited love

dt: {bc}a device that heats a gas by electrical means to form a plasma for high-temperature operations (such as melting metal)

shortdef: a device that heats a gas by electrical means to form a plasma for high-temperature operations (such as melting metal)

dt: {bc}to give one's job, duties, etc., to another person

dt.t: He is retiring and {it}passing the torch on{/it} to his successor.
She says she's ready to {it}pass the torch{/it}.

shortdef: to give one's job, duties, etc., to another person

dt.t: her legs refused to {wi}carry{/wi} her further

dt: {bc}to influence by mental or emotional appeal {bc}{sx|sway||}

dt.t: She intended the play to {wi}carry{/wi} audiences toward a sense of peace and understanding.

{bc}to contain and direct the course of
{bc}to wear or have on one's person

{bc}to have or bear especially as a mark, attribute, or property
{bc}to hold or comport (oneself, one's person, etc.) in a specified manner

{bc}to sing with reasonable correctness of pitch

{bc}to be chiefly or solely responsible for the success, effectiveness, or continuation of

dt.t: The bill was {it}carried{/it} in the Senate by a vote of 75–25.

dt: {bc}to present for public use or consumption
{bc}to bear the charges of holding or having (stocks, merchandise, etc.) from one time to another
{bc}to keep on one's books as a debtor

dt.t: The dog could not {wi}carry{/wi} the scent.

dt: {bc}to hoist and maintain (a sail) in use
{bc}to pass over (something, such as a hazard) at a single stroke in golf
{bc}to propel and control (a puck or ball) along a playing surface
{bc}to reach or penetrate to a distance

dt: {bc}to convey itself to a reader or audience
{bc}to undergo or admit of {a_link|carriage} in a specified way

dt: {bc}to have a gun on one's person {bc}to carry a gun

dt.t: I did make one adjustment in the aftermath of Ned's attack. I hauled my H&K [handgun] and holster out of the trunk at the foot of my bed. If Ned was declaring war, I'd be {wi}carrying{/wi}.

dt: {bc}to be in love especially without {d_link|reciprocation|reciprocation} {bc}cherish a longing or devotion

dt.t: still {it}carrying a torch{/it} for a former lover

dt: {bc}to perform or assume the chief role {bc}bear the major portion of work or responsibility

dt.t: No one else is available to make the arrangements, so it's up to you to {it}carry the ball{/it}.
Truth and justice will {it}carry the day{/it}.

et: Middle English {it}carien{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}carier{/it} to transport, from {it}carre{/it} vehicle, from Latin {it}carrus{/it} {ma}{mat|car|}{/ma}
